comments.commentBody:
The Jets have brought all this on themselves. Nob ody forced them to move into Giants Stadium as tenants and no matter what they try to tell you, the new Stadium is still Giants Stadium and always will be. They can cover u the Giants Super Bowl plaques all they want when they play home games there.

The Jets had every opportunity to continue and establish their own identity. His Excellency, Emperor Michael I, you know he that doesn't believe term limit laws should apply to him even though the pe3asants...oops public twice voted for a two term limit, tried to build them at taxpayers' expense a stadium on the West Side. Of curse he claimed it was for an Olympics bid but everybody knew the 2012 Olympics would rotate to a European city and the IOC was just using him to boost the price Paris and London were willing to pay. When this attempt at blackmail failed, Woody Johnson and the Jets should have looked to build a reasonably cheap football only stadium, they do exist, on Long Island or in Queens say in Willets Point where there was plenty of land available.

Instead since his attempt at blackmail had failed, Woody Johnson goes in and kisses the Giants' feet, pulls his corporate office and training facility away from the Long Island fan base and forever established the Jets as second class citizens in this region.

In doions so, they tried to inflict psl's on their fans and went through their entire waiting list for season tickets. What's next? Bringing in Peyton Manning?
That makes Gingrich the perfect villain. And the perfect villain is the ideal candidates for Democrats to run against.

That last line sums up the (real) reason why Apple won't manufacture in the US: because the company's business goals of "reinventing a product every year, making it better and faster and cheaper," etc., are simply incompatible with humane working conditions at its manufacturing plants.

Apple won't build here because they wouldn't get away with having a Foxconn-like factory in the US. Apple could and should do better.

Thank you NYT for publishing this story.

My oh my, all of a sudden it is very trendy to demonize Steve Jobs and sleek Apple products.

Well, you might want to hold you moral indignation. If you've ever shopped at WalMart or Target or made pretty much any buying decision on the basis of price, you've contributed to this state of affairs.

Do you think your kid's toys, or your kitchenware, or your clothes are made under any better circumstances?

The world economy is driven by billions of consumers making billions of purchasing decisions, not by evilness on the part of a few corporate titans. Price competition, supply and demand, technological advances enabling the global flow of goods and information has led to where we are...

Ah, the power of unrestrained capitalism.  As we move away from government oversight and put more trust in the "morality" of companies, we can expect this kind of labor exploitation to return to our country, as well.  Apple is no more and no less at fault than any contemporary US company. They are playing by the rules set up by our society. Every time you cast a vote for an "anti-government" candidate, you join in. What kind of world do you want? One where you can have cool gadgets and lots of cash in your pocket to buy blinders with? Does anyone remember the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire? The Johnston Flood? The Sub-Prime Mortgage catastrophe? When you trust big money business to do what's right, chances are it will be too late by the time you realize the mistake.

My oh my, all of a sudden it is very trendy to demonize Steve Jobs and sleek Apple products.

Well, you might want to hold your moral indignation. If you've ever shopped at WalMart or Target or made pretty much any buying decision on the basis of price, you've contributed to this state of affairs.

Do you think your kid's toys, or your kitchenware, or your clothes are made under any better circumstances?

The world economy is driven by billions of consumers making billions of purchasing decisions, not by evilness on the part of a few corporate titans. Price competition, supply and demand, technological advances enabling the global flow of goods and information have led to where we are...
My Macbook is almost 6 years old; I should get a replacement soon. But how can I buy from a company that exploits workers this way?   If we buy Apple products, we are complicit in this abuse.

"and, of course, watch all the advertisements."

Seems like the advertisements have just about as the same likelihood of being "true."

This article seems to be not only about Patrick Witt, but also about the propensity of sportswriters to weave easy myth, encouraged by our eagerness to accept it.  The Times is to be commended for going beyond individual indictment and taking this thoughtful approach.  We are all complicit to various degrees, cogs in the megabucks entertainment machine collegiate and professional sports has become.  This will be in the back of my mind when I read all the articles leading up to the Super Bowl, pull for the Giants -- and, of course, watch all the advertisements.

Eh, I don't think this is about sex. Considering the details of Mr. Witt's prior substantiated infractions, I see a different pattern emerging. Someone asks him to leave a bar and he pushes his way in--doesn't leave until he is in handcuffs. He is asked him to wait for an escort at a dorm that isn't his and he does the same. Perhaps the sexual assault, if it indeed did occur, involved his refusal to respect a boundry and leave when he is asked? Seems likely. His issue might be a deeply felt sense of entitlement he is willing to pursue to the point of inflicting mayhem. Creepy stuff. Good story, well told. I took the original story at face value, and feel duped and naieve.  Though I admit I love my football, it's disturbing to contemplate which of our collective values and priorities might have given Mr. Witt the mistaken notion that he should pursue his own desires regardless of the harm he is inflicting on others.

How true. Government can create the conditions for a healthy economy and booming middle class. This what President Obama proposes.

The Republicans are proposing that government create the conditions for a healthy 1%, period. The rest of the population can scrabble for the crumbs that fall from the table of the mega-wealthy.

This should be required reading for every student, voter, policy maker...!!!
Thank you
I'll take Walter one further, the GOP has only crazy and lies. Crazy is usually tried first and when the base doesn't accept crazy the lie is used as replacement.

I've a degree in Econ Geography, Law and lived in East Asia. The dynamic East Asian countries are always the same: Japan, S.Korea, Taiwan, China and Singapore.These countries are all different, but they all share Confucianistic cultural...and culture shapes institutions.

The East Asians, via Japan, have stumbled upon a new hybrid form of government: the mandarinate professional bureaucracy as a 4th Branch of Government.

Bureaucracies aren't very democratic, but they make it so by drafting into it preeminent talent based upon a comprehensive system of BLIND examinations. Society's best goes into running society. The system is respected by all, and so is the Bureaucracy, the policies they create, which is also expected to be brilliant. What they craft gets implemented.

In your book "Pop Internationalism" you said that there is no East Asian miracle. The amount of outputs there roughly equals the inputs. The real miracle was they found the discipline to make the inputs. That's the 4th branch.

They have developed highly sophisticated industrial policies that include things like subsidized and directed inputs (capital/talent), protection, clustering and 'compression' that spawns hyper intensive competition in a NEW industries. They purposely pursue middle class growth because that creates demand needed for economies of scale.

Meanwhile, the Republicans point at jobs moving to Asia as evidence that government can't create jobs while they decimate the middle class. Nuts!

Romney donated his inheritance to charity. All the money he made was his own.

Nice try to equate private equity with "vultures", but nobody with any intelligence will accept it. Private equity can only buy companies that are inefficiently managed and then improve their prospects. Sometimes saving the company means job cuts, but without private equity there was a good chance that the entire company would have failed, rather than trimming back jobs.

@ Concerned Reader-

Romney donated his inheritance to Brigham Young University to create the George W. Romney School of Business in honor of his father.

I'm just saying - it's not the same as giving it to the Red Cross or Doctors Without Borders.
And yet Govenor Romney gives $3.5 million a year to charity and V.P. Joe Biden gives $350.00, oh yes Al Gore gives $300.00. How fair is that?

The other unfairness with regards to Mitt Romney is how he made his money. First, he started life with a significant head start because his daddy was wealthy. Increased economic fairness would begin by restoring the estate tax rates of 2001 and close the loopholes that allow the wealthy to avoid the estate tax, which is the most meritocratic tax there is.

Second, Romney amassed his fortune through vulture capitalism - destroying other companies (i.e. firing workers, cutting wages and benefits, etc.) and feeding off of their carcasses. It is one thing when someone earns lots of money by creating something useful for society. It is another when they amass wealth by undermining the economic security of others.

Third, Romney's profiting relied heavily on corporate welfare from local, state, and federal government agencies. Coming from a guy who claims to be opposed to government spending, it is pure hypocrisy that Romney attacks programs that help people in need yet largely ignores the massive subsidies that taxpayers provide to the wealthy and corporations.

Fairness is about having an economy that rewards work, encourages investments that benefits society, and ensures that everyone pays their fair share. The economy that Romney benefited from and defends done none of those things.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

The drug companies also advertise and otherwise attempt to influence doctors. This is not entirely educational, keeping doctors on their toes. It is skewed marketing.

Doctors should take time with patients. However, they should not have to take time away from treating patients in order to counter the distortions that drug companies pay tens of millions of dollars to implant in consumers brains.

Actually, it should be "No, I don't have time to talk to you, but yes, I will accept all the free samples you have." There are a number of drugs I had prescriptions for (no, I didn't ask for them) when I was working and had private health insurance. The most effective of those drugs have had their patent terms lengthened from 21 years to who-knows-what (presumably by sampling the House and Senate). Meanwhile, the manufacturer brags at meetings of potential stockholders about how many BILLION dollars it earns each year from that one drug.

Obviously, no Part D policy (that's Medicare drug coverage for the younger folks who don't need to know yet) covers anything that's anywhere near as expensive as any of these drugs. It's expensive, but it works, at least for me. The only way I can get any of these expensive drugs I used to take is by getting samples at my doctor's office. Everyone wants those samples, so the doctor has to ration them. He or she cannot give a month's supply to one patient and tell the rest of the patients, "Sorry, you weren't here quick enough."

While most of these drugs work very well, some of them are life-saving. How does a doctor decide who among his or her poor, retired and on Medicare, or otherwise financially challenged patients should get a month's supply at each one-month follow-up visit?

When will Congress get some ethics? I know it's a stupid question, but I can dream, can't I?

Ciara, yes, you can dream but there's a pill for that now.

BTW, why don't you name the drug?

Physicians have a powerful and simple tool to counter this trend to direct consumer advertising. They can say "No." Not only "No, you don't need that medication," but also, "No, Ms. Drug Rep, I don't have time to talk to you today and I don't want your free samples."

That's the rub of it, no one should 'simply be encouraged to use kettlebells' - without quality instruction. Anything used incorrectly can produce vast potential for serious injury, not just kettlebells. The problem becomes when consumers mistakenly assume they know how to use something because they watched a video on youtube, or read an article in the NY times. Or perhaps they stayed at a Holiday inn Express last night. Would you use a firearm or motor vehicle before at least getting SOME instruction?
In the same way that using other weights incorrectly can also create potential for serious injury?

Moreso than other weights because kettlebells are tyically used "ballistically" as they were in this study, whereas regular weights are used in a controlled fashion.  As a trainer, I hear one or two stories a week about people hurting their backs with these.

This is an absurd study, it doesn't compare kettlebells to other forms of exercises.  And the kettlebell users were apparently professionally supervised.  What if they were simply encouraged to use kettlebells or used them on their own without supervision? Used incorrectly, there is potential for serious injury from kettlebells especially among people with pre existing back problems.

I've never felt that heels were obligatory either.  I think the shame is more that they feel that way.  It does seem that there are more heels than ever now when you shop for shoes.  Which is a pain in the neck - and also, to me, even offensive.  I don't think they look good either.  There are some very nice shoes to be found - and I think smart shoe people should be seeing the opportunities here for a whole market.  Healthy, attractive, and affordable shoes for women.  Men have a much better selection.  Women have pages and pages of spikes - which aren't shoes.
I think Earth Shoes would fall more in the orthopaedic category.

Indiawilks - I didn't say that Hillary Clinton was some paragon of feminism. However, she's not some raving idiot or wallflower either. Yes, she's got her issues, as do most people. Unfortunately, for her, her issues (aka Bill Clinton) were broadcast publicly for all to scorn and deride. As for choosing her, I'll be frank her name popped up first in my head and, honestly, I think first of her work product rather than her messy marital situation.

Regardless, Hillary Clinton is a feminist warts and all. I didn't realize being a feminist meant adhering to a strict code of conduct and behavior and being some flawless individual.
Heels make women look unstable, and that's how lots of men like 'em!

What heel height were the "heel-wearers" accustomed to wearing? It seems that would be a basic parameter the researchers would have established in their study. Without knowing the heel height, readers really can't take away any message from the researchers' findings. Especially since, in the past couple of years, super-high heels (4" and higher) have become very popular. Are we talking about 1.5" heels? 3"? 4.5"?

indiawilkes - just because you chose not to wear them doesn't mean it's a figment of my imagination or I'm feeble-minded. The same goes for my friends. Fyi, they also work at white shoe law firms. As for high heels, I don't mean that they are wearing 5" Louboutins. I mean 2"-3 1/2" heels. I have friends who despise wearing anything but flip flops and even they know they have to wear appropriate shoes with their conservative suits (sorry, but no frills on the hips).

Also, I'm baffled, but where the heck did you work that you had junior associates who wore cheap polyester suits and had decorated nails? Given how much first associates are paid, I don't know anyone who wore polyester. Yeah, wool gabardine suits from J Crew at first, but polyester?

It seems to me that you have a specific image in mind in regards to the type of person who wears high heels to work. I'm dumbfounded. Have we gotten to the point where wearing high heels is automatically equated with bad make up, cheap clothing, lack of confidence and feeble minds? If that's your line of thinking then I guess the next time I wear heels to work, I will need to somehow acquire a polyester suit, slab on copious amounts of garish make up, and decorate my nails. Given that I wear no make up, don't own a polyester suit and despise nail polish, it should be a challenge.
I bet you take off your high heels as soon as you get home, and never wear them when you're at home alone, right?

@ thomas bishop: Excellent sarcasm.  I've always wondered why some gay men would imitate the fashions of stereotypical women by adopting their oppressive apparel, including high heels. Are they crazy, or what?

I suppose many women undergo the knife for their own pleasure, along with the long list of strange behaviors American women indugle in to be beautiful (chemical hair straightening and coloring, skin pigment lightening and tanning, unhealthy dieting and debt just to name a few).

How old are you K, 22, under 30? The term "Walking Tall" has nothing to do with height, shoes or the style of clothing a person wears.

Everyone should have the right to dress according to their personal preference. But when someone feels positive mental energy wearing something that is documented to hurt you over a period of time, that makes me wonder about their mental capacity. As I stated at another post, at one time cigarette smoking was a sign of coolness, style and class.

I am also a lover of shoes, but stopped reading wierd Vogue so many years ago. Emaciated alien-like, wierd looking women in strange poses wearing $800 ugly dresses is such a turn off. No self-righteousness implied.

For my own pleasure -- I like knowing my feet are on the ground, I will be cheerful at the end of the day, and if necessary, I can climb a flight of stairs easily.

Wow! I read about fifty of the comments and saw exactly two defending a woman's right to shoes (thank you, Carrie Bradshaw, for the pun). How vain and self-absorbed of the male commenters to assume that women who wear heels are only doing so to appear "sexy" and "attractive" to the men who see them on the street; please, the dismissive, patronizing "sympathy" and musings re: the psychological issues of women are phony and unnecessary.

Did it ever occur to anyone that women wear high heels solely for their own enjoyment? I wear 4" heels daily to the office purely for pleasure (I'm an analyst at my state's education agency where the majority of employees wear tennis shoes with jeans - i.e. heels are not required footwear). We have the saying "walking tall" for a reason - high heels give you confidence! I love how powerful I feel when I am dressed up in a pencil skirt and heels - professional and business-like, not like I just threw on a pair of sneakers to run to the grocer. The benefits of the positive mental energy a hot pair of shoes gives you can outweigh the (potential) physiological negatives (whether your "hot" is a pair of Manolo's, Keen's, or those darn muddy Caterpillar workboots my ex-boyfriend was so fond of).

I think I speak for readers of Vogue/lovers of shoes everywhere when I say, "We appreciate your concern, but spare us the self-righteousness."

And for the record, my feet do not resemble "Chinese bound feet" - they are beautiful, with or without shoes!

Here is a little more about Green Garlic, unlike its mature garlic bulb parent, is a ninety day plant and not length of day sensitive. While the full size garlic bulb is a long day plant which requires the long days of June for it to mature, Green Garlic can be planted in successive increments allowing you to have a continuous supply of fresh garlicky goodness all summer long and into late fall. The bulbils or small cloves from seed garlic can be planted in the fall allowing you to have the earliest possible spring crop. To see the full article go to our web page

Rickertville garlic Farm

Eczema runs in our family. I have am aunt in her 60s who never dated or married or was able to get a good job and build a career because of her eczema and itching. SHe is doing OK now because of protopic and other new medicines, and just having gotten older, but she missed out on everything in life that is fun or brings happiness. My mom has it to a lesser extent. She told me their parents never touched or cuddled them. This disease really needs better more effective treatment. It ruins lives.

People do not enter nursing homes unless they are frail, by and large. The average length of stay in a nursing home is less than two years (although obviously this is highly variable). Nursing home residence is a proxy for poorer health status, and in particular, diminished capacity in things like cognitive function and balance.

My mother in law was not in a nursing home but was very frail and she declined precipitously after a relatively simple surgery for her veins. After being relatively stable (after a stroke) for close to seven years, she had surgery and declined until death over the next three months.

Mr. Hartman, my sympathy for the loss of your mother. Surgeons usually perform urgent or emergency colon surgery giving patients a colostomy when there is intestinal perforation from cancer or diverticulitis.  I am a surgeon who has been called numerous times, twice within the last few months to evaluate nursing home residents in the Emergency room with bowel perforation. Without surgery they both would almost certainly die but as this report shows with surgery there are very high risks with. I spent time with family and ministers offering options emphasizing their right to decline surgery and be sent to hospice. A majority of patients in my 30 year experience choose surgery or patients' families DEMAND it. Others complain of "death panels" .   I have prayed with patients hoping they would choose a peaceful passing and refuse surgery. This is not a black and white, right or wrong, yes or no issue but a complicated, multifaceted situation.
